newsitem.title: UK: GOLF-WATSON'S LIKING FOR LINKS TOOK TIME.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-WATSON'S LIKING FOR LINKS TOOK TIME.

text.p: When Tom Watson won his second British Open title in a scintillating shootout with Jack Nicklaus at Turnberry in 1977 it was not enough to turn him into a fan of links golf.
Though Turnberry provided Watson with "maybe the most satisfying victory I've ever had", it took a far less successful Open at Royal Lytham in 1979 to change his outlook.
"I played miserably there. I made the cut but I struggled the whole week," the five-times champion recalled on Wednesday.

"Until that time I didn't like links golf. I didn't like the bumps and the bounces and the so-called 'bad breaks'. I liked target golf. I liked hitting the ball through the air and stopping it. That's the way I learned when I was a youngster."
Having made the cut he shot 76-81 to finish joint 26th. "I said to myself, 'I didn't play well but I think I understand a little bit more about the game,'" said the American.

One hole in particular, he said, helped to sway him. "It was the par-five seventh. One day I played driver, three-wood, five iron, the very next day I played driver, nine iron because the wind switched."
Of the previous Open at the Royal and Ancient he said: "I didn't like St Andrews, the bumps and the shots it required you to make.
"But I thought more about it in '79 and I said, 'This is not just a game of targets and through the air and yardages. This is a game of shot-making values'."
Of his 1977 Turnberry success he said: "I played golf more through the air there. Here at Troon, you have to play a little more on the ground, like St Andrews.
"It requires some skills you don't normally see pros using."
The 47-year-old Watson, who ended a nine-year drought on the U.S. Tour by winning the Memorial Tournament last year, said his present game "is not particularly good."
"It is not as good as I would like it right now. It is not in the state that it has been when I have won tournaments."
He said he had made a couple of recent changes which he was happy with "but I wish I had a couple more days of practice with it before I put it to the test."
Watson's five wins put him second on the all-time list with three other players, one behind Englishman Harry Vardon who won six between 1898 and 1914.
Asked what one more victory would mean to him, Watson replied: "Move over Harry!"
